image.altText: King Charles inside a coach

items.synopsis: Thousands of people have gathered along the procession route to catch a glimpse of King Charles III and Queen Consort Camilla ahead of the coronation. Follow live.

title.children: King Charles III heads to London's Westminster Abbey ahead of procession

schema.headline: Live updates: King Charles III heads to London's Westminster Abbey ahead of procession

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Queen Camilla waves to well-wishers
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The procession is now entering its final phase as it makes its way up Whitehall. The King and Queen have just passed No. 10 Downing Street and are now approaching Big Ben. They'll round the corner into Parliament Square, and enter through the Westgate of Westminster Abbey.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: King Charles departs Buckingham Palace
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: And we're seeing more footage now of this procession making its way from Buckingham Palace to Westminster Abbey.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Prince Harry has arrived
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: King Charles' youngest son has entered with his cousins, Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie. Harry's wife, Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, is not attending and is staying in California with the couple's two children.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Ladies and gentlemen, Sam Kerr
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Spot the Matilda's captain Sam Kerr? Here's another wrap up of the prominent figures and Commonwealth leaders arriving for the ceremony.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: More on those very important horses
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By Jacqueline Howard in London The six horses pulling the Diamond Jubilee State coach have been carefully selected for the responsibility. Icon, Shadow, Milford Haven, Echo, Knightsbridge and Tyrone are all Windsor Greys, and their manes have been dyed a royal blue for the occasion. On the way back to Buckingham Palace, Meg and Newark will join their stablemates to make the eight-horse team that will pull the ancient Gold State coach.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Camilla no longer 'Queen Consort', says palace
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: From reporter Nick Dole Even before Camilla arrived at Westminster Abbey, her title had been changed on the royal website to "Her Majesty, the Queen." There had been clues this change was coming, as the official coronation invitations referred to her as "Queen Camilla." However, it's a major departure from what some members of the public had been expecting. When she married Charles in 2005, Clarence House suggested Camilla could be known as the "Princess Consort" when her husband was crowned. Then, shortly before the Queen Elizabeth's death in 2022, she said it was her "sincere wish" that Camilla be known as "Queen Consort" when that time came. There are still some admirers of Princess Diana who find it hard to see Camilla sitting on the throne, let alone being called "Her Majesty, the Queen." The title change will eventually stick, if the palace pushes it. But that doesn't mean everyone will like it.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Queen Consort Camilla accompanies King Charles
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: You can see them both sitting in the Australian-made Diamond Jubilee Coach here.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Australian landmarks light up purple to mark King's Coronation
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: If you're out and about while all this is going on, keep an eye out for various landmarks around the country to light up purple.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: How you're all spending tonight
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Weâ€™re up in Queensland for a family wedding and have now all packed into the bar to watch! Will it be Kingsland by the end of the night? - Meg Doing the ironing n watching ABC ( of course!) - Paul

liveBlogUpdate.headline: King Charles makes his way to Westminster Abbey ahead of coronation
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: King Charles III is making his way to Westminster Abbey in the Diamond Jubilee Coach for the first coronation in 70 years. You can hear thousands of people cheering as the procession makes its way down The Mall.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Guests seated inside Westminster Abbey
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Not long to go now! Here's another overview of the inside of Westminster Abbey, so you can all take a moment to play spot that famous face.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: King's carriage made in Australia
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: And here's video of that Australian-made carriage rolling out (does this give us extra coronation clout or?)

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Our first sneak peak of King Charles and Queen Consort Camilla
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: We've received the first images of King Charles and Queen Consort Camilla sitting in Diamond Jubilee State Coach at Buckingham Palace.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: We've just spotted the Diamond Jubilee Coach
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: And she's a beauty! Almost all of the craftsmanship was sourced from within Australia, with the exception of the two  door handles, made by a New Zealand jeweller, which are individually decorated with 24 diamonds  and 130 sapphires, and the glass in the lamps, made by Edinburgh Crystal. The Australian-made Diamond Jubilee state carriage will be used for the trip to Westminster Abbey, while the much bumpier 18th Century gold state coach will transport them back to Buckingham Palace after the ceremony. The coach is drawn by six Windsor Greys:  Icon, Shadow, Milford Haven, Echo, Knightsbridge and Tyrone.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Anti-monarchy group says hundreds of placards seized
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Anti-monarchy group Republic says five of its supporters have been arrested and hundreds of its placards seized. A Reuters photographer said a number of Just Stop Oil protesters were also arrested.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: One hour to go until the coronation kicks off
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: How are you spending your night? Anyone having a little coronation party? Let me know in the comments!

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Ukraine's First Lady is here
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: First Lady of Ukraine Olena Zelenska and the Prime Minister of Ukraine, Denys Shmyhal have arrived at the King's coronation.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Here's what those on the tube have been hearing this week
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By Jacqueline Howard in London Those travelling into central London via the Underground for the coronation will hear some familiar voices echoing through the subway halls this weekend. "My wife and I wish you and your families a wonderful coronation weekend," King Charles says. "Wherever you're travelling we hope you have a safe and pleasant journey," Camilla says. "And remember: Please mind the gap," Charles says.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Jill Biden arrives at Westminster Abbey
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: No sign of US President Joe Biden yet, but photos have just dropped of first lady Dr Jill Biden.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: King Charles treated people as equals, says author
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: British-Australian author Kathy Lette as told ABC TV King Charles III is the "opposite" of upper-class Brits. "Most upper-class you have to do open heart surgery to see what's going on inside them," she said. "But he's always been so passionate and so open about his care of our great planet, for example." Check out the full interview below.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Prince Andrew arrives
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Will Prince Andrew be making an appearance? - Peter File. Yes, we've just spotted Prince Andrew leaving Buckingham Palace en route to Westminster Abbey.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Celebrations have started in the town of Lenakel on the Vanuatu island of Tanna
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Preparations to celebrate the coronation of King Charles III have started in the town of Lenakel on the Vanuatu island of Tanna. Villages on the island recognise King Charles' father, Prince Philip, as a manifestation of an ancient warrior leader. A celebration will be held later today at the kastom village of Yahunannen where villagers will pass on their allegiance to the new king.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Procession begins on route to Westminster Abbey
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: As guests take their seats inside the abbey the first procession of the day is already marching through the streets.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Here's how Western Australia celebrated the coronation today
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The Government House ballroom in WA has been opened to the public, with families and residents in Perth invited to take photos with portraits of King Charles and Queen Consort Camilla, and write their well-wishes to the Royals in books. WA Governorâ€™s wife Darrilyn Dawson welcomed expats and Australians alike to the ballroom, which hosted a crowd of a few dozen people. â€œItâ€™s been wonderful to have families coming through. Children learning about what itâ€™s all about, the government and the importance of the coronation. Itâ€™s obviously a very historic situation here.â€ Among those attending was the Uckiah family, who lived in the UK for 14 years and now reside in Perth. â€œItâ€™s a once-in-a-lifetime event â€¦ [visiting Government House] is for the kids to understand there is tradition still around, the importance of understanding those structures in the world and the role of the Royal families in peace in the world,â€ said mother Vidoula. Some members of the public wore crowns and donned royal colours in celebration of the day.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Let's check out some other famous faces
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The coronation is still 1.5 hours away and yet Westminster Abbey is nearly at full capacity as guests continue to arrive.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Maggie Smith, Emma Thompson and more arrive
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Spotted any other famous faces in the crowd yet? Here's a quick compilation of the celebs who've arrived so far.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: King Charles arrives at Buckingham Palace
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: King Charles III has arrived at Buckingham Palace from Clarence House ahead of his coronation ceremony.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: King Charles promised a 'slimmed down' coronation, but the total cost is still under wraps
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: By Europe bureau chief Steve Cannane The palace has promised a "slimmed down" coronation. But is that what we will be seeing today? It you compare it to the 1953 coronation there with be about a quarter of the guests, a shorter ceremony and procession, but the costs will remain high. The government has kept the price tag a secret, but some estimates put it at Â£50-100 million. A lot of Brits are unimpressed that so much public money is being spent in the middle of a cost-of-living crisis. A recent YouGov poll found that 51% of those surveyed did not think the coronation should be paid for with taxpayers' money, 32% though it should, 18% said "don't know". Lauren Woodfine, a tattoo artist from Lancashire told me, "He's just becoming King, just put your hat on". Michael Glenn, the town crier of Morecambe, has a different view. "I understand that the cost of living is absolutely dreadful for everybody. But I think what it (the coronation) will bring to the country outweighs the cost."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Lionel Richie takes his place in Westminster Abbey
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: It was announced last month that Lionel Richie and Katy Perry would be among the lineup of stars to perform at Charles' coronation concert this weekend.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Police arrest republican leader ahead of coronation, group says
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: British police have arrested Graham Smith, leader of an anti-monarchist group Republic, ahead of King Charles' coronation, a spokesperson for the group said. Police did not confirm the arrest, saying they did not immediately name those arrested. A photo posted on Twitter showed Smith sitting on the ground surrounded by a group of police officers. An officer at the scene said three republican protesters had been arrested.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Who or what are we most excited to see tonight?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I love the pomp and ceremony and looking out for the famous faces. - Rae Same, Rae! I'm keen to see all the coronation fashion from the royals, especially from Catherine, the Princess of Wales. Who or what are we most excited to see tonight? And how is everyone celebrating tonight? Let me know in the comments!

liveBlogUpdate.headline: We're on the ground outside Buckingham Palace
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Here's another quick update from our Europe correspondent Isabella Higgins, who is right in the thick of it. Royal fever is red hot down at Buckingham Palace. Crowds are coming in thick and fast, adorned in their best Union Jack-inspired clothing. Itâ€™s a sea of red, white and blue. Theyâ€™ve come from near and far, young and old, coming together to see this spectacle. The military band can be heard rehearsing in the distance. These crowds are gripped with anticipation and excitement.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: 'No one does pomp and pageantry like the British'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: From Europe correspondent Isabella Higgins Sindy Viney (L) has travelled from the Central Coast in New South Wales to be at the coronation. "I love the ceremony â€¦ the pomp and pageantry, no one does it like the British." While camping out she's befriended Nina Hosking a local London resident who woke up at 4am to travel to Buckingham Palace. "My mother was here at the Queen's coronation, she's 88 and she wanted to be here today," she said. "She was 17 and slept overnight to see it â€¦ so I'm really here representing her and being part of a moment in history."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: WATCH: Julian Leeser says Coronation celebrates office above politics
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The Liberal MP says he thinks of Australia as having an Indigenous heritage, British foundation and multicultural character.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Emma Thompson is also in attendance
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: I've just spotted British actor Emma Thompson arriving at the coronation with her husband Greg Wise.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Nick Cave has arrived at King Charles' coronation
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: He's here! Earlier this week the Australian musician defended his decision to attend King Charlesâ€™s coronation. Writing in his online blog The Red Hand Files, Cave has explained his decision to attend had less to do with his political leanings and more to do with his love of pageantry. "I am not a monarchist, nor am I a royalist, nor am I an ardent republican for that matter," he wrote. "What I am also not is so spectacularly incurious about the world and the way it works, so ideologically captured, so damn grouchy, as to refuse an invitation to what will more than likely be the most important historical event in the UK of our age."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: How can I watch the coronation in Australia?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Live coverage and commentary started at 5pm AEST on ABC News, with the official ceremony starting at 8pm AEST. You can watch proceedings as they happen on ABC iview, and if you miss any of the action you can catch up post-event. I've also added the ABC live stream to the top of the blog, and of course I'll be bringing you all the action right here.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: What time will Charles be crowned King?
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The ceremony will officially start at 11am UK time today, May 6. For Australians that will be 8pm AEST tonight. While the ceremony will start at 11am, proceedings â€“ including King Charles and Queen Consort Camilla's journey to the cathedral in a carriage â€“ will kick off around 10:20am UK time, which is 7:20pm AEST .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Welcome to the coronation of King Charles III
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Hello and welcome to our live coverage of the coronation of King Charles III, it's lovely to have your company. It's been 70 years since we witnessed the coronation of the longest-ruling monarch in British history â€” Queen Elizabeth II. Now, in just a few short hours, millions of people across the world will tune in to watch as her son, King Charles, is crowned the new monarch. Crowds have been gathering for days outside Westminster Abbey, and now thousands of people are lining the procession route hoping to catch a glimpse of Charles and Camilla. I'm Jessica Riga and, together with my colleagues, we'll be bringing you all the latest updates and reactions from London and around the world. So let's kick things off!

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: From reporter Nick Dole Even before Camilla arrived at Westminster Abbey, her title had been changed on the royal website to "Her Majesty, the Queen." There had been clues this change was coming, as the official coronation invitations referred to her as "Queen Camilla." However, it's a major departure from what some members of the public had been expecting. When she married Charles in 2005, Clarence House suggested Camilla could be known as the "Princess Consort" when her husband was crowned. Then, shortly before the Queen Elizabeth's death in 2022, she said it was her "sincere wish" that Camilla be known as "Queen Consort" when that time came. There are still some admirers of Princess Diana who find it hard to see Camilla sitting on the throne, let alone being called "Her Majesty, the Queen." The title change will eventually stick, if the palace pushes it. But that doesn't mean everyone will like it.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: British-Australian author Kathy Lette as told ABC TV King Charles III is the "opposite" of upper-class Brits. "Most upper-class you have to do open heart surgery to see what's going on inside them," she said. "But he's always been so passionate and so open about his care of our great planet, for example." Check out the full interview below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: King Charles treated people as equals, says author

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Preparations to celebrate the coronation of King Charles III have started in the town of Lenakel on the Vanuatu island of Tanna. Villages on the island recognise King Charles' father, Prince Philip, as a manifestation of an ancient warrior leader. A celebration will be held later today at the kastom village of Yahunannen where villagers will pass on their allegiance to the new king.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Government House ballroom in WA has been opened to the public, with families and residents in Perth invited to take photos with portraits of King Charles and Queen Consort Camilla, and write their well-wishes to the Royals in books. WA Governorâ€™s wife Darrilyn Dawson welcomed expats and Australians alike to the ballroom, which hosted a crowd of a few dozen people. â€œItâ€™s been wonderful to have families coming through. Children learning about what itâ€™s all about, the government and the importance of the coronation. Itâ€™s obviously a very historic situation here.â€ Among those attending was the Uckiah family, who lived in the UK for 14 years and now reside in Perth. â€œItâ€™s a once-in-a-lifetime event â€¦ [visiting Government House] is for the kids to understand there is tradition still around, the importance of understanding those structures in the world and the role of the Royal families in peace in the world,â€ said mother Vidoula. Some members of the public wore crowns and donned royal colours in celebration of the day.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Here's how Western Australia celebrated the coronation today

props.alt: People stand around a photo of Charles and Camilla.

children.content: (ABC News: Kenith Png)

The Government House ballroom in WA has been opened to the public, with families and residents in Perth invited to take photos with portraits of King Charles and Queen Consort Camilla, and write their well-wishes to the Royals in books.

props.alt: A grand ballroom.

children.content: (ABC News: Kenith Png)
WA Governorâ€™s wife Darrilyn Dawson welcomed expats and Australians alike to the ballroom, which hosted a crowd of a few dozen people.

â€œItâ€™s been wonderful to have families coming through. Children learning about what itâ€™s all about, the government and the importance of the coronation. Itâ€™s obviously a very historic situation here.â€
Among those attending was the Uckiah family, who lived in the UK for 14 years and now reside in Perth.

props.alt: A family sits together in front of two grand red velvet chairs.

children.content: (AB News: Kenith Png)

â€œItâ€™s a once-in-a-lifetime event â€¦ [visiting Government House] is for the kids to understand there is tradition still around, the importance of understanding those structures in the world and the role of the Royal families in peace in the world,â€ said mother Vidoula.
Some members of the public wore crowns and donned royal colours in celebration of the day.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Europe bureau chief Steve Cannane The palace has promised a "slimmed down" coronation. But is that what we will be seeing today? It you compare it to the 1953 coronation there with be about a quarter of the guests, a shorter ceremony and procession, but the costs will remain high. The government has kept the price tag a secret, but some estimates put it at Â£50-100 million. A lot of Brits are unimpressed that so much public money is being spent in the middle of a cost-of-living crisis. A recent YouGov poll found that 51% of those surveyed did not think the coronation should be paid for with taxpayers' money, 32% though it should, 18% said "don't know". Lauren Woodfine, a tattoo artist from Lancashire told me, "He's just becoming King, just put your hat on". Michael Glenn, the town crier of Morecambe, has a different view. "I understand that the cost of living is absolutely dreadful for everybody. But I think what it (the coronation) will bring to the country outweighs the cost."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: King Charles promised a 'slimmed down' coronation, but the total cost is still under wraps

children.content: By Europe bureau chief Steve Cannane
The palace has promised a "slimmed down" coronation. But is that what we will be seeing today?
It you compare it to the 1953 coronation there with be about a quarter of the guests, a shorter ceremony and procession, but the costs will remain high.
The government has kept the price tag a secret, but some estimates put it at Â£50-100 million.

props.alt: Crowds gather underneath a coronation flag.

children.content: (Reuters: Henry Nicholls)
A lot of Brits are unimpressed that so much public money is being spent in the middle of a cost-of-living crisis.
A recent YouGov poll found that 51% of those surveyed did not think the coronation should be paid for with taxpayers' money, 32% though it should, 18% said "don't know".
Lauren Woodfine, a tattoo artist from Lancashire told me, "He's just becoming King, just put your hat on".

Michael Glenn, the town crier of Morecambe, has a different view. "I understand that the cost of living is absolutely dreadful for everybody. But I think what it (the coronation) will bring to the country outweighs the cost."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: British police have arrested Graham Smith, leader of an anti-monarchist group Republic, ahead of King Charles' coronation, a spokesperson for the group said. Police did not confirm the arrest, saying they did not immediately name those arrested. A photo posted on Twitter showed Smith sitting on the ground surrounded by a group of police officers. An officer at the scene said three republican protesters had been arrested.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Police arrest republican leader ahead of coronation, group says

props.alt: Anti-monarchists protest behind well wishers

children.content: (Sebastien Bozon/Pool via REUTERS)
British police have arrested Graham Smith, leader of an anti-monarchist group Republic, ahead of King Charles' coronation, a spokesperson for the group said.
Police did not confirm the arrest, saying they did not immediately name those arrested.
A photo posted on Twitter showed Smith sitting on the ground surrounded by a group of police officers. An officer at the scene said three republican protesters had been arrested.

Let me know in the comments!

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Here's another quick update from our Europe correspondent Isabella Higgins, who is right in the thick of it. Royal fever is red hot down at Buckingham Palace. Crowds are coming in thick and fast, adorned in their best Union Jack-inspired clothing. Itâ€™s a sea of red, white and blue. Theyâ€™ve come from near and far, young and old, coming together to see this spectacle. The military band can be heard rehearsing in the distance. These crowds are gripped with anticipation and excitement.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: We're on the ground outside Buckingham Palace

children.content: Here's another quick update from our
Europe correspondent Isabella Higgins
, who is right in the thick of it.
Royal fever is red hot down at Buckingham Palace.
Crowds are coming in thick and fast, adorned in their best Union Jack-inspired clothing. Itâ€™s a sea of red, white and blue.

Theyâ€™ve come from near and far, young and old, coming together to see this spectacle. The military band can be heard rehearsing in the distance. These crowds are gripped with anticipation and excitement.

children.content: (ABC News: Isabella Higgins)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: From Europe correspondent Isabella Higgins Sindy Viney (L) has travelled from the Central Coast in New South Wales to be at the coronation. "I love the ceremony â€¦ the pomp and pageantry, no one does it like the British." While camping out she's befriended Nina Hosking a local London resident who woke up at 4am to travel to Buckingham Palace. "My mother was here at the Queen's coronation, she's 88 and she wanted to be here today," she said. "She was 17 and slept overnight to see it â€¦ so I'm really here representing her and being part of a moment in history."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'No one does pomp and pageantry like the British'

children.content: From Europe correspondent Isabella Higgins
Sindy Viney (L) has travelled from the Central Coast in New South Wales to be at the coronation.
"I love the ceremony â€¦ the pomp and pageantry, no one does it like the British."

props.alt: Two women smile and pose for a photo.

children.content: Sindy Viney and Nina Hosking
(ABC News: Isbaella Higgins)
While camping out she's befriended Nina Hosking a local London resident who woke up at 4am to travel to Buckingham Palace.
"My mother was here at the Queen's coronation, she's 88 and she wanted to be here today," she said.
"She was 17 and slept overnight to see it â€¦ so I'm really here representing her and being part of a moment in history."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: He's here! Earlier this week the Australian musician defended his decision to attend King Charlesâ€™s coronation. Writing in his online blog The Red Hand Files, Cave has explained his decision to attend had less to do with his political leanings and more to do with his love of pageantry. "I am not a monarchist, nor am I a royalist, nor am I an ardent republican for that matter," he wrote. "What I am also not is so spectacularly incurious about the world and the way it works, so ideologically captured, so damn grouchy, as to refuse an invitation to what will more than likely be the most important historical event in the UK of our age."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Nick Cave has arrived at King Charles' coronation

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Live coverage and commentary started at 5pm AEST on ABC News, with the official ceremony starting at 8pm AEST. You can watch proceedings as they happen on ABC iview, and if you miss any of the action you can catch up post-event. I've also added the ABC live stream to the top of the blog, and of course I'll be bringing you all the action right here.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ceremony will officially start at 11am UK time today, May 6. For Australians that will be 8pm AEST tonight. While the ceremony will start at 11am, proceedings â€“ including King Charles and Queen Consort Camilla's journey to the cathedral in a carriage â€“ will kick off around 10:20am UK time, which is 7:20pm AEST .

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello and welcome to our live coverage of the coronation of King Charles III, it's lovely to have your company. It's been 70 years since we witnessed the coronation of the longest-ruling monarch in British history â€” Queen Elizabeth II. Now, in just a few short hours, millions of people across the world will tune in to watch as her son, King Charles, is crowned the new monarch. Crowds have been gathering for days outside Westminster Abbey, and now thousands of people are lining the procession route hoping to catch a glimpse of Charles and Camilla. I'm Jessica Riga and, together with my colleagues, we'll be bringing you all the latest updates and reactions from London and around the world. So let's kick things off!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Welcome to the coronation of King Charles III

props.alt: Charles and Camilla wave.

children.content: (Reuters: Phil Noble)
Hello and welcome to our live coverage of the coronation of
King Charles III
, it's lovely to have your company.
It's been 70 years since we witnessed the coronation of the longest-ruling monarch in British history â€”
Â
Queen Elizabeth II.
Now, in just a few short hours, millions of people across the world will tune in to watch as her son, King Charles, is crowned
Â
the new monarch.
Crowds have been gathering for days outside Westminster Abbey, and now thousands of people are lining the procession route hoping to catch a glimpse of Charles and Camilla.
I'm
Jessica Riga
and, together with my colleagues, we'll be bringing you all the latest updates and reactions from London and around the world.
So let's kick things off!

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: King Charles' youngest son has entered with his cousins, Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie. Harry's wife, Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, is not attending and is staying in California with the couple's two children.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prince Harry has arrived

props.alt: Prince Harry.

children.content: (Reuters: Dylan Martinez)
King Charles' youngest son has entered with his cousins, Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie.
Harry's wife, Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, is not attending and is staying in California with the couple's two children.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: King Charles III is making his way to Westminster Abbey in the Diamond Jubilee Coach for the first coronation in 70 years. You can hear thousands of people cheering as the procession makes its way down The Mall.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: King Charles makes his way to Westminster Abbey ahead of coronation

children.content: King Charles III is making his way to Westminster Abbey in the Diamond Jubilee Coach for the first coronation in 70 years.

props.alt: Charles sits in a gold coach.

children.content: (Reuters: Hannah McKay)
You can hear thousands of people cheering as the procession makes its way down The Mall.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: And she's a beauty! Almost all of the craftsmanship was sourced from within Australia, with the exception of the two  door handles, made by a New Zealand jeweller, which are individually decorated with 24 diamonds  and 130 sapphires, and the glass in the lamps, made by Edinburgh Crystal. The Australian-made Diamond Jubilee state carriage will be used for the trip to Westminster Abbey, while the much bumpier 18th Century gold state coach will transport them back to Buckingham Palace after the ceremony. The coach is drawn by six Windsor Greys:  Icon, Shadow, Milford Haven, Echo, Knightsbridge and Tyrone.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: We've just spotted the Diamond Jubilee Coach

children.content: And she's a beauty!

props.alt: A gold carriage is pulled along by horses.

children.content: (Reuters: Matthew Childs)

The Australian-made Diamond Jubilee state carriage will be used for the trip to Westminster Abbey, while the much bumpier 18th Century gold state coach will transport them back to Buckingham Palace after the ceremony.
The coach is drawn by six Windsor Greys:  Icon, Shadow, Milford Haven, Echo, Knightsbridge and Tyrone.

image.altText: Bodhi Mani Risby-Jones paraded by Indonesian authorities in balaclava and jumpsuit

title.children: Australian admits to rampage in Indonesia after being paraded in prison jumpsuit

image.altText: A young man smiles at the camera in a black and white image taken in a busy indoor location.

items.synopsis: UniversityÂ student Alex Shorey, who unknowingly ingested rat poison in Taiwan, thanks everyone responsible for helping him return to Australia, as he continues to recover in hospital.Â

title.children: Australian Alex Shorey speaks from hospital after ingesting rat poison in Taiwan

image.altText: Office workers with woman in sleeveless top

items.synopsis: An audit of the Australian Public Service workforceÂ has found that $20.8Â billionÂ was spent hiring tens of thousands of external contractors and consultants in the 2021-22 financial year, most of which saw the Liberal-National Coalition in power.Â

title.children: Public service audit reveals $20.8 billion outsourcing bill for last year of Morrison government

image.altText: an Indigenous man with a gas flare behind him.

items.synopsis: The Northern Territory'sÂ Chief Minister Natasha FylesÂ saysÂ "Aboriginal territorians have the power to veto"Â a gasÂ project.Â But is the matter really thatÂ straight forward?

title.children: Do Indigenous people have the right to veto gas projects in the Beetaloo Basin?

image.altText: Ukrainian soldiers watch drone feeds from an underground command centre.

items.synopsis: Analysts say Ukraine has drones capable of reaching MoscowÂ and Russia has increasingly claimed Kyiv's weapons have been getting closer to the capital. But the circumstances of the Kremlin strike remain "curious".

title.children: Is Ukraine's UJ-22 drone capable of carrying out a Moscow strike?

image.altText: Tight headshot of Queensland police commissioner Terry Lewis speaking to the media in Brisbane in the 1980s.

items.synopsis: The first serving Australian police commissioner to be knighted was jailed in 1991 for official corruption after being named in the Fitzgerald Inquiry.Â

title.children: 'He was an evil man': Whistleblower says former police commissioner Terry Lewis 'perverted the job'

image.altText: Man in Istanbul

items.synopsis: Chinese holiday-makersÂ say they want to come to Australia,Â but some travellers are having their tourist visa applications rejected.

title.children: 'They all thought I was joking': Chinese travellers surprised at Australian tourist visa refusals

image.altText: A group of people in face masks in an office with people in police uniforms in the foreground

items.synopsis: International alarm has grown in recent months over internet scams in the region often staffed by trafficking victims tricked or coerced into promoting bogus crypto investments.

title.children: Philippines authorities rescue more than 1,000 trafficking victims forced to run online scams

image.altText: Fijiana Drua celebrate with the Super W trophy as fireworks go off behind them

items.synopsis: Fijiana Drua claimÂ back-to-back Super W titles in just their second season in the competition with a pulsating 38-30 win over the Queensland Reds in Townsville.

title.children: Fijiana Drua become Super W champions again as Reds suffer more grand final heartache

image.altText: King Charles III smiling in a crowd of people waving small United Kingdom flags

items.synopsis: To take the coronation seriously would be to try to make sense of an Australian prime minister pledging his allegiance to a crown that tried to exterminate my people. For people like me, absurdity may be the only sane response, writes Stan Grant.

title.children: When the Queen died, I felt betrayed by a nation. Today, I feel something quite different

image.altText: Group of police officers at a Service NSW centre

items.synopsis: Mahmoud Salhab, accused of stabbing a Service NSW employee, remains in his cell as a court is told the 37-year-old is "not mentally in a stable position".

title.children: Man accused of stabbing Service NSW worker poses risk to prison officers, court told

image.altText: An Austrlain $2 coin has a picture of helicopter surrounded by bands of colour and the words "Vietnam war".

items.synopsis: Vietnam's communist government is demandingÂ Australia cease issuing commemorative coins that, it says, show the flag of the toppled US-backed South Vietnam, a claim Canberra denies.

title.children: Vietnam government furious about release of Australian commemorative war coins

image.altText: Chalmers points in front of his face. He's standing in front of flags.

items.synopsis: Workers will have to wait another year before their wages outstrip the rising cost of living, according toÂ Treasury forecasts to be released next week.
